content: My header currently uses {{site.data.fhir.ig.name}}, but in R4 that is the "computer-friendly" version of the name (and doesn't allow spaces or other human-friendly characters). I tried replacing with {{site.data.fhir.ig.title}}, but that did not do the trick (it evaluates to empty string). Is there a way to get to the IG title value in a Jekyll template?
{{site.data.fhir.ig.title}} should work if your IG has a title defined. Look inside your temp/_data/fhir.json file to see if it's propagating properly.
Unfortunately, the title is not anywhere in temp/_data/fhir.json. I have the title in ig.xml and ig-new.xml. I even tried putting it in ig.json -- but no matter what, it's not available in Jekyll.

I just found this workaround from @Eric Haas that seems to confirm he ran into the same problem:
https://github.com/HL7/US-Core-R4/commit/f217bc5ea8e5690159c660c5132dfd1af2e75f6a
Except I'm not using the same framework, so I have no _config.yaml file to add the missing variable to (i.e., this specific workaround won't work for me).
That's weird unless the code got yanked from the IGPublisher yet again...
I'm using org.hl7.fhir.publisher.cli-0.9.5-20190505.003301-1.jar -- so unless it was fixed since May 5th, perhaps it was yanked.
I can try a new publisher tomorrow just to be sure. Thanks for the responses, @Lloyd McKenzie.
put the _config.yml in the same folder as your layouts or _includes it should work too. @Chris Moesel is correct, there is no {{site.data.fhir.ig.title}}
I'm working on putting it back. It's supposed to be there.

Thanks for the tip, @Eric Haas -- but putting _config.yaml in my _includes folder didn't work (and I don't have a layouts folder). That said, I noticed that the title seems to be available at site.data.pages["index.html"].title, so I ended up adding this code into the template wherever I need to access the title:

{% assign title = site.data.fhir.ig.title %}
{% unless title %}{% assign title = site.data.pages["index.html"].title %}{% endunless %}
{% unless title %}{% assign title = site.data.fhir.ig.name %}{% endunless %}

This covers the bases so that when site.data.fhir.ig.title is available, it will use it; otherwise it falls back to the location I discovered it (but is undocumented); otherwise it just falls back to the IG name. Seems to work.

That is indeed a clever hack. Each page has a title and that assumes the index.html = ig title. you are able to define that in the ig.xml file so you have control there. The _config.yml should be in the same directory as the _includes not inside it.

I must admit I could not get it to work forever then tried it again (mostly because Lloyd got it working) and it worked. It may be because I updated my version of Jekyll/Ruby I forget the details.
